entry.title: Combined summary - Update on "Speedy" Trial: The circus rolls on
entry.summary: Recently, there has been controversy in the Bitcoin community over the use of a coin toss to make a technical decision regarding the activation mechanism for Taproot, Bitcoin's upcoming upgrade. The decision was between two competing methods proposed by Jeremy Rubin and Dave Harding. While some members of the community expressed disapproval of using such informal methods, others like Andrew Poelstra stated that they don't care about the activation parameters and suggested a coin toss if necessary.Michael Folkson expressed discomfort regarding the controversy surrounding Taproot and its impact on businesses worldwide. He feared that important decisions were being taken too lightly. However, ultimately, a compromise solution was found, and progress on Speedy Trial is expected to continue. There is nearly universal support for Taproot among the community.The recent debate over how to implement Taproot in the Bitcoin network has sparked discussions about better activation mechanisms for future deployments even before Taproot reaches activation. There is an open core PR for Speedy Trial (#21377) that appears to be the best chance of getting activation code merged into Core. The more testing and code review this core PR receives the better. If it continues to make progress, the discussion will then need to move onto a timetable.The email exchange between developers of Bitcoin's Core software raised concerns about the use of a coin toss to decide whether to deploy a key upgrade. It sparked fears that important decisions were being taken too lightly. This series of events has left some individuals feeling uncomfortable and concerned about the impact on businesses planning to utilize and build on Taproot. Michael Folkson, an individual who wishes to distance himself from this circus, has provided two StackExchange links on block height vs MTP for those interested in the technical considerations.
